resources.name: crop_data

fields.name: harvest_year
fields.title: Year in which crop harvested
fields.description: Year in which the crop was harvested.

fields.name: crop
fields.title: Crop in this harvest year.
fields.description: Crop grown in this harvest year. Winter wheat, except in 1930 when the winter wheat failed and it was re-sown with spring wheat (see note 3). Fallow (no crop) in 1927, 1928, 1934, 1935.

fields.name: plot
fields.title: Plot
fields.description: Original plots established in 1877

fields.name: sub_plot
fields.title: Sub-plot
fields.description: Some plots were divided into a and b halves from 1882-1907 to test different treatments. See plans

fields.name: sub_sub_plot
fields.title: Sub sub-plot
fields.description: Some sub-plots were divided into i and ii halves, from 1905-1915 to test different treatments. Sub-plot a divided into i and ii (formerly known as aa), sub-plot b into i and ii (formerly known as bb).  See plans for details

fields.name: old_plot_notation
fields.title: Original plot notation
fields.description: Original plot name from Russell and Voelcker (1936) data tables. This was updated to current plot names to make sub-plots clearer.

fields.name: fertilizer_code
fields.title: Fertilizer code
fields.description: Code describing the fertilizer applied in that harvest year. No fertilizer (none) applied 1927-1940, N applied to all plots, 1941 and 1942.

fields.name: fertilizer_n_amount
fields.title: Fertilizer N amount
fields.description: Total inorganic nitrogen fertilizer applied in this harvest year. Applied as ammonium sulphate.

fields.name: fertilizer_n_date
fields.title: Date fertilizer N applied
fields.description: Date the nitrogen fertilizer was applied

fields.name: sow_date
fields.title: Sowing date
fields.description: Date the crop was sown, usually in the autumn of the year before the crop was harvested.

fields.name: harvest_date
fields.title: Harvest date
fields.description: Date the crop was harvested

fields.name: cultivar
fields.title: Cultivar
fields.description: Wheat cultivar (variety) grown in this harvest year

fields.name: plot_area
fields.title: Plot area
fields.description: Plot area. Each full plot was 0.10 hectare, some were then divided into a and b halves (0.05 hectare) and quarters (i and ii) (0.025 hectare).

fields.name: bushel_weight
fields.title: Bushel weight
fields.description: Bushel weight. The weight in kg of a bushel of grain at threshing. A bushel is a volume measurement, assumed to be 36.369 litres

fields.name: hectolitre_weight
fields.title: Hectolitre weight
fields.description: Hectolitre weight, kg of grain per 100 litres.  A measure of grain quality. Calculated from bushel weight, assuming 1 bushel is 36.369 litres

fields.name: grain_yield
fields.title: Grain yield
fields.description: Harvested wheat grain yield at 85% dry matter. Fallow (no crop) yields shown as blank cell. If a crop was sown but it failed, yield shown as 0.0

fields.name: straw_yield
fields.title: Straw yield
fields.description: Harvested wheat straw yield at 85% dry matter. This does not include stubble. Fallow (no crop) yields shown as blank cell. If a crop was sown but it failed, yield shown as 0.0

fields.name: note_id
fields.title: Note identification
fields.description: Whether notes are applied or not. See notes_data for details

resources.title: crop yield data
resources.description: The main data table containing annual winter wheat grain and straw yield data for all plots and sub-plots  of the Woburn Continuous Wheat experiment, 1927-1942. Also grain bushel weights and hectolitre weights, a measure of grain quality. With agronomic information, including fertilizer, sowing date, plot size and cultivars. No fertilizer was applied 1927-1940, and the experiment was used to look at the residual effects of fertilizer applied from 1877-1926. In 1941 and 1942, basal N fertilizer was applied at the same rate to all plots. The whole experiment was fallowed (no crop sown) in 1927, 1928, 1934 and 1935 (yields shown as blank cells).  See notes for more details. This experiment is a companion to the Woburn Continuous Barley experiment.

resources.name: notes_data

fields.name: note_id
fields.title: Note identification
fields.description: Note number

fields.name: description
fields.title: Description
fields.description: Additional explanatory notes for records in the crop_data table

resources.title: Notes
resources.description: Additional explanatory notes for records in the crop_data table

name: woburn-continuous-wheat-experiment-yields-1927-1942
title: Woburn Continuous Wheat Experiment yields 1927-1942
description:
### Abstract
Annual wheat grain and straw yields for all plots and sub-plots of the Woburn Continuous Wheat Experiment, 1927-1942, with treatment details. Also grain hectolitre weights, a measure of grain quality. This experiment is a companion to the Woburn Continuous Barley Experiment.
### Methods
The Woburn Continuous Wheat Experiment started in autumn 1876, with a range of fertilizer and manure treatments applied until 1926. No fertilizer was applied 1927-1940, and during this period the experiment was used to look at the residual effects of fertilizer applied from 1876-1926. In 1941 and 1942, basal N fertilizer was applied at the same rate to all plots. The whole experiment was fallowed (no crop sown) in 1927, 1928, 1934 and 1935.
### Technical Info
Harvested wheat grain and straw yields at 85% dry matter. Fallow (no crop) yields shown as blank cell. If a crop was sown but it failed, yield shown as 0.0. Straw yield does not include the stubble or all the chaff. Hectolitre weight, kg of grain per 100 litres, calculated from bushel weights, assuming 1 bushel is 36.369 litres. Winter wheat sown every year, except fallow years (no crop) and 1930, when the original winter wheat crop was so badly damaged by birds it had to be re-sown with spring wheat.
### Provenance
Individual plot yields were taken from Rothamsted Experimental Station Annual Reports, 1927-1938 and Yield Books 1939-1942. Agronomic information (sow dates, cultivar, etc) taken from Annual Reports, Yield Books, plans and descriptions in the Rothamsted Library archives. The frictionless dataset of combined yields and treatment data was compiled by Daniel Philcox and checked by June Kimori and Margaret Glendining, July 2022.
### Quality
In accordance with the Joint Code of Practice for Research at Rothamsted, data processing in e-RA follow rigorous standard operating procedures to ensure the quality and correctness of data collected in the field through to depositing in the e-RA database. To ensure quality control during data inputting, the data sets were typed on two separate occasions (double data entry). During the second typing (verification) the data values were compared with those typed on the earlier occasion, and any discrepancies were resolved before verification continued. This procedure avoided visual checking of data, which can be very inaccurate.

contributors.title: Margaret Glendining
